narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic understanding of global affairs; broad and deep understanding of key world issues; implications of things like technology, education, climate change on a global scale; learned a lot about Iraq
basic global affairs

This was an incredible course and I learned so much about the middle east, China, Russia/Ukraine, and so much more. This course was incredibly comprehensive in not just studying foreign affairs but also in different sectors such as public health, education, and circular economies.
introduction to global affairs
I gained a lot of background knowledge around many global affairs' topics.
A survey of the issues plaguing the world, with a focus on the Middle East.

I learned a significant amount about current political events in the Middle East, with particular regards to the Iraq War. We did not learn much about issues in Europe and barely spoke about Africa. I would have liked to learn less about problems in America.

I was provided a survey of many of the most significant global challenges society faces today. I learned that everything is more complex and high stakes than it seems. I am very interested in the global affairs major thanks to this course.
A broad overview of global politics today.
a better understanding of current events and US involvement in the middle east
Difference between empathy and sympathy; more knowledge and deeper understanding on global events; how to write a policy proposal; interviewing and reaching out to people
I developed a better understanding of how the world works and how to make a change in it. Great emphasis on the Middle East.

I developed an overall understanding of pressing issues and global matters around the world. In the beginning of the semester, there was a focus on the Middle East, but later on, we also discussed topics including climate change, food security, and education.
I learned a lot about international relations and how to complete effective presentations.
A great overview of recent global affairs
I learned more about the current affairs and pasts of different regions around the world as well as some of the current pressing global issues.
Insights to and analysis of the background, politics and society of countries around the world (including relations between nations) as well as issues facing the global community.
I got a much better understanding of the global political scene and was introduced to several global topics with a particular emphasis on conflicts in the Middle East.
More knowledge about world events in the past 30ish years
I gained a critical insight into a broad range of important global issues.
I learned how to watch the lectures and read articles and pull the information I needed for the discussion.
A global view of recent history, war/conflicts, and relevant current worldly topics.

During this course, I learned the principles of analyzing issues from a more global perspective. In doing this, I reviewed articles and participated in discussions that brought the readings to life and conversation.
An understanding of how the world's connections and country's dependence on one another as well as a deeper comprehension of how current events evolved through history.
Understanding the world affairs in a nutshell

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Very broad range of topics covered, great experience with TFs, consistent interaction with peers, encouragement to be engaged in class, variety of ideas and understandings welcome, diverse lecturers and journalists in materials
Weakness: Not all students did the readings each week because there was no way to verify if they had been done; weekend homework was almost overwhelming if I did all the readings, since my reflections were due Tuesday 4 am and materials weren't posted until 5 pm the preceding Fridays.
The discussion sections were an amazing resource of the course.
There could be more organization, but it was well taught.
I'd like to have a wider variety of readings. Sometimes, it felt like we dedicated A LOT of time to Middle East but skimmed over many other areas of the world.

The section on the Middle East (roughly the first half of the course) is very strong. Professor Sky's experiences make this the highlight of the class. However, the rest of the class consisted of online videos and articles.

It was very difficult to remain engaged in the course after the professor stopped posting virtual lectures and instead posted Youtube documentaries. We also only had the privilege of speaking directly to our professor two times this semester. The level of reading was very manageable and engaging, however, and I highly recommend trying to get into a small discussion section. The midterm was particularly frustrating because I read the professor's book twice, yet still found the prompts difficult to decipher and adequately answer.

Strengths: spectacular lectures from Professor Sky and excellent discussions in section. Impactful readings
Weaknesses: lack of consistency as semester went on. Sky's lectures stopped and eventually lectures stopped altogether. I really missed these later in the semester. They were a highlight of my experience at Yale thus far.

A strength is that the course content was interesting and professor brought fascinating real world experience. A weakness is that for the second half of the semester we didn't even have lectures. We would just watch youtube videos and read articles.
The course was very strong in getting students engaged with discussions. A lot of emphasis on the middle east so maybe more time spent on other events

Strengths: manageable workload; passionate TAs and professor regarding the topics we talk about in class; both a strength and a weakness but putting giving students vague guidelines and expectations allowed us to have some creativity with our work

Weaknesses: not enough guidance for the students, kind of just like "here's the work, do it". as a first-year, this was kind of difficult; rules and expectations were kind of vague; extremely disliked the "wow factor" as part of the midterm rubric --> i do not believe that 4 out of 20 points of our midterm papers should be part of our grade. If anything a "wow factor" should only be a bonus point or two. I also felt like most of the information we learned in this class could've been done on our not, not necessarily at Yale. 

Not really a weakness, but I think the students just really wished we could meet with the professor more.

The course content is very engaging. However, only interacted with Professor Sky three times this semester:  her greeting during the first section, her book discussion, and during my final presentation. I would've appreciated seeing more of her much more.

We had a weekly discussion section, in which we talked about the lecture and readings. The discussions were informative and allowed me to hear and understand different perspectives. I think the course was disproportionally focused on the Middle East, as we devoted more than half of the semester to affairs in the Middle East.

The breadth of topics is both a strength and weakness as it was all very interesting and great to see how everything connects, but it also meant that lectures were very long and there were a LOT of readings every week. It was kind of hard to keep up!

Loved the final project

Some strengths of this course were the amount of information presented and the opportunity to hear from guest lecturers and people at the Jackson Institute. However, this course was heavily skewed on the political spectrum and the required articles for weekly reading lacked variety in political thought and bias. In addition, some of the information presented in recorded lectures was either historically inaccurate or left out crucial details when attempting to retell history, particularly in modules on the MENA region. This created an echo chamber of a discussion section and likely provided students with an inaccurate account of history on certain conflicts or events.
TA was very good at facilitating discussion sections

This being a survey course brings unavoidable weaknesses such as the speed at which material is covered and the lack of depth that results from that. However, there's not really a way to change that. That being said, I think this course found a good balance since the Middle East was extensively covered while the other topics were quickly skimmed.

The first half was good. I really enjoyed Prof. Sky's lectures. As soon as she stopped giving it the lectures it went downhill. Watching a youtube seminar or something wasn't as good as what she could've done. I really liked her history lessons about the middle east conflicts as well as her book, so I wish there was more of that.
The global issues we learned about were very well selected!

Strengths - Section was fun and a new topic was covered each section

Weaknesses - Could be too broad and lectures fell off at the end of the course.

I believe the strength was the discussion section, mainly because I had a great TF. This course could be improved by the professor making the lectures more interactive. This could be done through more lecture slides.

The recorded lectures were good, but the level of engagement with Professor Sky is low. Most of the course was run by the TFs. The material is interesting, but there is a lot of material covered each week.
This course's subject matter was fascinating--I only wish that Prof. Sky was more involved as her viewpoint is incredibly unique and valuable.
The content seems a little bit shallow though the scope is very broad

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the recorded lectures were difficult to follow, since the PowerPoints only flashed on the screen for a few seconds at a time.
I think if we could have had lecture-style classes with the professors instead of recorded lectures that would have been great in order to form bonds with the professor.
the module format was very helpful.

I believe the professor should continue with the virtual lectures, but they should keep lecturing for the entirety of the semester. I greatly enjoyed the final project, which involved researching current issues in the New Haven area and writing a policy brief with our recommendations on ways Yale can work better with the New Haven community.
All was adapted adequately. Of course, I know no other situation.
The lectures were intersting; however, I would have liked there to be more opportunities to interact with the professor such as Q&A sessions.
discussion sections were strong. a possible more clear way to find all necessary readings and lectures
Given our situation, I think the class did its best it could.

Instead of interesting lectures, the course quickly evolved into a series of news articles and Jackson Institutes recordings. A better mode of engagement would've been nice, especially one where students could've interacted with guests and the Professor a lot more.

I think the weekly discussions, conducted over Zoom, were still very engaging and interactive. The lectures were recorded beforehand and thus less interactive. I wish there were more opportunities for us to interact with Professor Sky.
All succeeded!
Discussion section format is very effective. The discussion format really helped the students analyze and discuss about global issues

I think this course did what it could with the virtual format. Having a live virtual seminar definitely gave the class a sense of consistency although I wish it had been longer. 

Comments on the readings were due a very awkward time before class and it disincentivized me from putting much effort into it. 

I found that with any class on Zoom the more time spent in smaller groups of maybe 4 or 3 the easier it was to be involved because with bigger groups it was very easy to just sit back and be passive.
The practices in this course geared towards learning during the COVID-19 pandemic all worked well.
I liked the structure of having a lecture to watch then a more organized discussion. This made it easier to get immediate feedback.
More recorded lecture was needed.
The prerecorded lectures aspect of this course could be improved for virtual engagement.
The recorded lectures were good as students could watch them at their leisure.
The recorded lectures from the first half of the course were incredible and very helpful--near the end, when we switched to only articles and youtube videos, the course felt a bit detached.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student interested in majoring in Global Affairs. Comprehensive introduction to the subject and very interesting, engaging TFs.
Yes, interesting material for background information and not too hard at all
ABSOLUTELY! I had an incredible time in the course and I learned so much every single week
Yes! Great course to take no matter which major. It teaches some really important global affairs history that is just good to know as a human being on this earth.
Yes, if you want an overview of what the global affairs look like currently but aren't searching for a deep-dive into any particular topic.

It's an okay class. Grading is a bit sporadic and the conversations are often shallow. Imagine a global affairs class with lots of first-year wannabe State Department ambassadors. That's a good picture of the class.
Absolutely. Fascinating content. The survey style of this class could possibly illuminate a passion.
I would not. If you just read the news I think you would learn as much as you would by taking this course.
Yes, for students interested in American politics or government I would reccomend this course

Depends. The class didn't turn out to be the way I had imagined it, but this is also my first year at Yale. I think still for an introductory course for global affairs, this does get the job done for teaching students about recent important global events. However, I feel like much of what I learned in this class did not require coming to Yale. I could've researched all of this on my own elsewhere.
While it gives a great overview of Global Affairs, it is probably much better in person. It's an easy class to take during an online semester.

I would recommend this course because you gain an overview of global issues. I would especially recommend this for anyone interested in Middle Eastern politics because most of the course focuses on affairs in the Middle East.
Yes!
Yes! Great introduction to global affairs

If the student is interested in global affairs, I would say yes, I would recommend this course. Just be aware that the course, particularly in this virtual format, is highly dependent on your TF and that the course may lack diversity of political thought. My TF did not even attempt to remain politically unbiased. This created a poor environment for expressing thoughts beyond the popular beliefs and made discussion sections quite boring.
Yes
Yes if you're interested in global affairs/international relations
I'd recommend it but survey courses are dreadful in the virtual format so do it when it's in person.
I think so, Prof Sky is pretty cool and is a good lecturer but just know that you'll only get to hear from her for half the course.
This course gives students good insight into a multitude of important world issues and is a must take course.
yes
Yes! This class is super fun and gives you a broad understanding of a myriad of topics.
Yes, but I would recommend choosing a great TF.
Yes, it is a very helpful overview and foundation for anyone interested in global affairs of America's involvement in the middle east.
Yes
